newsitem.title: USA: Cyberonics ready to sell device in U.S..
newsitem.headline: Cyberonics ready to sell device in U.S..

text.p: Cyberonics Inc is ready to begin selling its implantable vagus nerve stimulator for treating epilepsy in the U.S., which it plans to price at $9,000 to $10,000.

"We will list the entire systeM for between nine and ten thousand dollars," said John Bakewell, chief financial officer, in a telephone interview Wednesday. "That is comparable with other electromechanical implants."

Cyberonics said earlier Wednesday it received approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to market its NeuroCybernetic Prosthesis System for the treatment of patients for whom other antiepileptic therapies are not effective.
Cyberonics stock was up 1-3/8 to 8-7/8 in late afternoon trade, after having traded as high as 9-1/4 on the news.
The company already has approval to sell the device in Europe.
Bakewell said that the U.S. market presents opportunities that are not present internationally.
"Patients with epilepsy in the U.S. tend to take a (more) active interest in the therapies being used and are quite proactive in requesting therapies," Bakewell noted.
"Third party payment for products tends to be more straightforward and generous than what is typically seen in the international market place," he added.
